close_symbols: lfs_file_t (type definition and member layout: off, flags, m, cache, block, id)
structure/type of file->cache and lfs->pcache/rcache (type definition and member layout: buffer, block, off, size)
explanation: To determine whether lfs_file_relocate uses any compiler language extensions you must inspect any macros, types, and called functions whose definitions might themselves employ extensions (GCC/clang __attribute__, statement-expressions ({...}), typeof, inline asm, __extension__, nonstandard calling conventions, etc.). For each listed symbol: - Macros (LFS_MKTAG, LFS_DEBUG, PRIx32): macros often expand to nonstandard constructs (statement-expr, typeof, format specifiers, compiler intrinsics). Their definitions must be checked for extensions. - Types and struct layouts (lfs_t, lfs_file_t, lfs_block_t, lfs_off_t, uint8_t, cache struct, lfs->cfg): type definitions or struct member declarations can include compiler extensions (packed, aligned, __attribute__, bit-field uses, anonymous structs/unions, extension keywords). Inspecting the full type/struct definitions is required. - Flag/constant macros (LFS_ERR_CORRUPT, LFS_F_INLINE, LFS_F_WRITING, LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT): macros or enum definitions may use extension syntax or rely on nonstandard integer-width assumptions. - Called functions and their declarations/definitions (lfs_alloc, lfs_bd_erase, lfs_dir_getread, lfs_bd_read, lfs_bd_prog, lfs_cache_zero, lfs_cache_drop): function prototypes or implementations may use inline, __attribute__, nonstandard calling conventions, statement-exprs, or other extensions that affect conformance; check their headers/definitions. - Standard library call (memcpy): confirm the declared prototype in included headers is standard and not replaced by a compiler-specific builtin or macro. Collecting these symbols (and inspecting their definitions) is sufficient to determine whether any language extensions are used either in lfs_file_relocate itself or in the macros/types/functions it directly relies on.
